thread.title: Gus Malzahn 13th highest-paid college football coach, per USA Today
thread.title_full: Gus Malzahn 13th highest-paid college football coach, per USA Today | AL.com

author: James Crepea | jcrepea@al.com
title: Gus Malzahn 13th highest-paid college football coach, per USA Today
text:
Gus Malzahn remains just outside the top 10 highest-paid college football head coaches but was dropped back slightly both nationally and in the SEC from a year ago, according to an annual database compiled by USA Today .
Auburn's third-year head coach is slated to earn $4,104,500 this season, ranking 13th nationally and sixth in the SEC, down from 12th and fifth, respectively, last year , according to the report.
Malzahn is in the second year of a six-year contract he signed two days before the 2013 SEC Championship Game but Auburn (3-2, 0-2 SEC) is struggling in many facets and has dropped from the preseason favorite to win the SEC and contend for a spot in the College Football Playoff to out of the polls.
While Malzahn jumped South Carolina's Steve Spurrier ($4,028,600) in the rankings from a year ago, he slipped behind Ole Miss' Hugh Freeze ($4,310,000) and Georgia's Mark Richt ($4,124,000), who trailed Malzahn last year.
Malzahn will also make $4,500 in other pay, according to the database, which tracks both school pay and other income earned from coaching.
Alabama's Nick Saban ($7,087,481) remains the highest-paid college football coach in the country and Texas A&M's Kevin Sumlin ($5,000,000) and LSU's Les Miles ($4,385,567) are still second and third in the SEC, which had all 13 of its public school coaches among the top 27 salaries -- Vanderbilt's Derek Mason not accounted for because it is a private school that does not disclose contracts.
Originally hired to a $2.3 million contract in Dec. 2012, Malzahn ranked 11th in the SEC in total salary during the 2013 season, when he led the Tigers to the SEC Championship and the greatest turnaround in conference history.
To see the full report, visit USA Today .
